												Hexcells is a puzzle game not unlike minesweeper. Not to say that this is a rip-off, but the game does fall into that puzzle genre, so those who like cleaning up the fields based on surrounding information of placement of "mines" will dig this game as well.The main difference from minesweeper in your Windows is that slots are hexes and that the puzzles are pre-made, not randomly generated. And while hex form doesn't make much of difference, it's the fact that puzzles are pre-made that makes this game THE thing. Those of you who enjoy playing Mines sure remember the times when the randomly generated field would give you a situation that you simply can't solve logically, only by guessing (dang corners!). Not in this game. All 30 puzzles are cleverly crafted to make sure that there is always enough of information at any moment for the next step. It's great to know that there is always a way to proceed, you just have to recheck everything and figure out the patterns.Well, it would have been great, but Hexcell 1 is mostly a tutorial title in series. out of 6 worlds, 5 of them introduce new elements, ways of thinking and are easy to beat. Real challenge comes only in final world puzzles, that is 4 pieces plus 1 bonus. If you plan to get only one Hexcells, then you should go for Plus or Infinite, which (re)introduce elements quick enough and then it's pure challenging field cleaning.I also don't approve the game letting player to just click on everything on the field. While the game punishes it by giving less points, that you need to proceed to the next worlds (and for perfect achievement), the puzzles don't change when and you can just remember the placement of blue fields and redo it perfectly, in a cheap way. Just don't do it. For your own enjoyment. Ok?Art is minimalistical. Artistical minimalism. Minimalism artistico. Usual spacey ambient soundtrack. Doesn't take away attention. Some may like it. I only like music that can also be heard in the trailer and that's about it.So, people who like minesweeper puzzles should pick this one along with whole Hexcells bundle. Posted: April 14, 2016
												Puzzle games that take a familiar mechanic and add a simple set of twists can definitely go one way or the other: really good, or horribly bad. Occasionally, I buy one on a whim and am granted with a brilliant experience, as I was with Lyne. This has happened not just once again, but three times with Hexcells, Hexcells Plus and Hexcells Infinite. For the sake of brevity, what follows covers all three, but the TLDR is that if you like puzzle games, buy Hexcells.Graphics 9/10Visuals are always big with me, and these games are beautiful with simple, clean imagery and colours. But this beauty has function: the orange, blue and charcoal colour scheme means you know very clearly what each cell is. The small animations when you hover over or click on a cell are nicely done as well. While it's not perfect, I have only very minor issues with particular aspects of each iteration of Hexcells; so small I won't even mention. But if you're a fan of minimalist design, this is a great example.Audio 9/10The minimalism here continues, with more variety however. Although I generally turn off music in games, I did take the time to sample it in all three iterations of Hexcells. I'm a fan of ambient electronic, and found it very fitting. Combined with the visuals, it made me think of games like flOw. The samples used when clicking on cells continue the minimalist electronic theme, with some levels using piano-type sounds while others sounded more like raindrops or wee bells. With that said, after having to redo some levels again and again, I turned off the sound completely. And speaking of level design …Gameplay 10/10Have you played Minesweeper? This game is to Minesweeper, what DOOM was to Wolfenstein. The basic gameplay was very similar, but suddently there is more depth, more challenges, more variety. And while I liked Minesweeper back when I first got Windows 95, I found it too repetitive. Hexcells however, introduces enough new mechanics, not to mention board design, that I could play this game continually.Replayability 9/10In fact, that's part of what Hexcells Infinite is about, with a level generator built in that uses a random seed to create as many levels as you wish to play. Though the pedant in me wants to say: an 8 digit, whole integer seed won't give me infinite levels, but that is such a tiny quibble. ;) Still, overall, with dozens of levels pre-built in each of the three versions of Hexcells, and the near-infinite custom levels in one version, there is plenty of replayability.Overall 9/10If you like puzzle games, buy Hexcells. If you have a friend who likes puzzle games, buy Hexcells for him/her. As of this writing, you can get all three versions for $9.99CDN, and at that price, it's a good deal. If you can snag it on sale, even better. Add on the fact that it works on Windows, Mac and Linux, and there's really no good reason not to support a developer like this. My only hope is they can follow it up with another game that is as brilliant.

												I love this game. Hexcells takes the classic game of Minesweeper and pushes it to a whole new level. Instead of squares, you get hexagons - this sounds more difficult, and some of the levels are pretty challenging, but it was a great improvement. There's no guessing, either; you're always given just enough information to complete the level with zero mistakes. You can listen to the ambient, relaxing music as you test your brain with these 36 levels.Not only are there numbers on the hexes, but once you get far enough there are also line headers (numbers above rows or beside columns) as well as counters on some of the blue tiles that tell you how many blue hexes are within the highlighted area. I think this game is unique, intuitive and overall very satisfactory. I got it on sale for less than a dollar, but I would have purchased it at full price. It's worth it.If you're looking to test your puzzle solving skills, this game (and the entire series) is something to try out.

Posted: January 3, 2016
												80 minutes to get 98%. Recommended for fans of Minesweeper/Picross, at the price that you feel is appropriate for about 1.5 hours of play.I have a fair amount of experience with Minesweeper and Picross-style puzzles, so this felt straightforward and fun. Hexcells ends up using the same logic you'd use for those games. All puzzles are 100% prove-able; there's no forced guessing between multiple spaces. I didn't notice anywhere that I had to string together much "if this, then this, then this, no that won't work"...no giant cascading logic messes. Comfortable and casual all the way through.Some cautions: -- Unlike some similar games, you aren't marking tiles in a toggle-able way. That is, once you left- or right-click on a tile, it will immediately be shown to be correct or incorrect (which costs you a mistake). -- To me, the default left and right click felt backwards. I restarted the game and swapped them in the pre-game settings window with no problem. -- I played through almost the entire game in a windowed smaller resolution. Puzzle 29 did not fit entirely in the window, and I couldn't find any way to scroll or scale so I could see the whole puzzle. I had to exit back out and start again with non-windowed 1080p, since I figured that would be safe for all puzzles. -- The level select screen does not seem to indicate which puzzles you used a "mistake" on, so it looks like it would be annoying to go back and figure that out after the fact. I'd recommend that you immediately retry puzzles if you're aiming for the (very obtainable) perfect achievement, or at least write down which puzzles you'd need to retry later.Don't get me wrong, these cautions are all very minor. I enjoyed this quick game.

												Hexcells is a delightful little puzzle game, a bit like minesweeper but much more interesting and well-built. Unlike Minesweeper, you never need to guess in Hexcells - using the hints provided at the beginning of the level, you can work your way to a completed field using logic alone. If you're a fan of sudoku or Minesweeper, I can guarantee you'll enjoy this game.As the first game in the series, it lacks a bit of the polish of later entries (saving partially completed puzzles isn't added until the third installment) and it's a little to easy to get to the end (I got perfect on all stages in less than four hours taking my time), but it serves as a great introduction to the much more challenging later games. I reccomend picking up all three games on sale as I did - the difficulty scales is such a way that it feels like playing through one larger game.Overall, a really refreshing, if somewhat easy, puzzle game. Grab the sequels if you want more polish and challenge.

Posted: February 27, 2015
												I bought this short but sweet game when it was on sale for 50 cents. I didn't expect much, so it was a pleasant surprise to find a true logic game.Though Hexcells borrows elements from several different puzzle games, I was most reminded of nonograms, also known as Picross or Hanjie, which I've solved hundreds of by hand and in video games. As with nonograms, the game's beauty lies in the fact that the rules are are simple and it is purely logic-based (instead of relying on gimmicks or time-limits). That means that even in the later puzzles, which can be a bit challenging, you never have to resort to guess-work and anyone can solve them easily with enough focus and time.It's true the game was far too short (you can get 100% completion in a few hours), but now that I've tried it I would recommend it even at full price, though of course preferably wait for a sale. Apparently, the third installment has a random puzzle generator, which soundss like exactly the kind of thing this kind of game needs, but I will have to try it to see. Regardless, this game has proven the concept amazingly well and given my brains a few solid hours of work to do for the price of a cup of coffee.

												80 minutes to get 98%. Recommended for fans of Minesweeper/Picross, at the price that you feel is appropriate for about 1.5 hours of play.I have a fair amount of experience with Minesweeper and Picross-style puzzles, so this felt straightforward and fun. Hexcells ends up using the same logic you'd use for those games. All puzzles are 100% prove-able; there's no forced guessing between multiple spaces. I didn't notice anywhere that I had to string together much "if this, then this, then this, no that won't work"...no giant cascading logic messes. Comfortable and casual all the way through.Some cautions: -- Unlike some similar games, you aren't marking tiles in a toggle-able way. That is, once you left- or right-click on a tile, it will immediately be shown to be correct or incorrect (which costs you a mistake). -- To me, the default left and right click felt backwards. I restarted the game and swapped them in the pre-game settings window with no problem. -- I played through almost the entire game in a windowed smaller resolution. Puzzle 29 did not fit entirely in the window, and I couldn't find any way to scroll or scale so I could see the whole puzzle. I had to exit back out and start again with non-windowed 1080p, since I figured that would be safe for all puzzles. -- The level select screen does not seem to indicate which puzzles you used a "mistake" on, so it looks like it would be annoying to go back and figure that out after the fact. I'd recommend that you immediately retry puzzles if you're aiming for the (very obtainable) perfect achievement, or at least write down which puzzles you'd need to retry later.Don't get me wrong, these cautions are all very minor. I enjoyed this quick game.

YouTube™ Video: Indie Mon: Hexcells 

			Views: 16		

			Kick back for a relaxing puzzle game called Hexcells today. Well relaxing in the Sudoku sense. Hexcells puts you in charge of what hexagons need to be changed, or not.		

Yesterday I had a headache, and was searching for a game that I could play to get my mind off of it. I wanted something without action, and I wanted to listen to some of my own relaxing music. I knew a puzzle game would be a perfect fit, and that's how I came across Hexcells. So I put on my music, and got right to the relaxing world of math.Hexcells is a game where a bunch of hexagons come together, and you must figure out if the orange hexagons are blue, or a number. Sound simple sure, but how does one figure out this crazy math! Each puzzle starts off showing some numbered hexagons. This number is equal to the amount of blue hexagons that are touching it. So if it says four that means four blue hexagons are touching, and if it says zero then that means no blue ones are touching.Let's stay with the zero example for a little bit. So if it says zero then you'll want to right click all the hexagons that are touching it. This gives you more options to play around with as it opens up more of the playing field. For another example lets move on to if the hexagon says one. Since this one already is touching a blue hexagon then you can right click on all the other hexagons touching this hexagon with the number one.Hexcells was a great way to just kick back, and play a mindless game that actually requires some brainpower. Think of it like a Sudoku, or word search puzzle. You're using your brain, but it's not something you have to concentrate too hard on.As Hexcells carried on it added more rules to it. One for example was having numbers at the top, or sides of the puzzle. When you see this number that's telling you how many blue hexagons are in that row. There's more to the world of Hexcells, but that's for you to find out about.It took me a little over two hours to beat Hexcells, and I was kind of sad it was over so soon. I want more puzzles! I really enjoyed my time figuring out these puzzles, and think if you're a fan of Sudoku puzzles, or puzzles in general you'll enjoy Hexcells. Worth the price of $2.99, and worth your time.

Posted: March 31, 2015
What is Hexcells?Hexcells is a puzzle game that looks rather like Minesweeper. Players are presented with an orange grid comprised to hexagons and it is up to them to determine whether these cells belong to the blue pattern or not (black cells). The black cells not part of the pattern have a number in them to indicate how many blue cells are adjacent to them, thus providing a clue as to how to proceed.After completing a puzzle the player is awarded blue hexcells based on the amount of mistakes made; these in time accumulate to unlock one of five new areas - allowing you to complete more difficult puzzles. Some areas also introduce new clues and rules to help you, making the puzzles more complex over time. Although similar to Minesweeper as mentioned, there is a key difference: there is always a logical next step. You never have to take a gamble so if you feel stuck, take a step back and focus on another area.Why I recommend the gameHexcells is a very simple puzzle game in its visual design. The menu is simple and provides the players with the option of turning the ambient music on or off and selecting one of three save slots. The same can be said for the puzzles themselves; a grid of hexagons on a white backdrop. To me this is good design, as I'm here for the puzzles and that's where the focus clearly lies.The 30 puzzles themselves are interesting and there are enough additions in terms of new rules/clues during the course of a playthrough to keep them fresh and interesting. I just wish there were more.However, this does not mean that the game is without flaws. For instance, it is not possible to erase a save slot so starting completely from scratch is not an option if all three slots are in use. Furthermore, the puzzles tend to be on the easy side, for me anyways.My biggest problem with the game is that there is no option to save mid-puzzle forcing you to either finish it or redo the part you already completed next time.All that being said, I've had a lot of fun playing this game and would recommend it as the pros outweigh the cons for me. I would encourage those interested in puzzle games to give this one a try.

Posted: June 28, 2015
												Hexcells is one of the best puzzle game experiences I've had.It starts off with a simple Minesweeper-like premise. After a few levels, the game begins its brilliance by adding new types of clues beyond "three of the surrounding hexes are empty," turning the game into something resembling a nonogram-like puzzle (the kind of puzzle featured in Nintendo's Picross games). These mechanics are backed up by excellent puzzle design and an ambient soundtrack that keeps players relaxed and focused as they work their way through the puzzles.The only serious flaw in the game is that there isn't any replay value. There is still quite a bit of skill in repeating the large puzzles without making a mistake, but gradually players will remember the patterns and can cheat by learning from previous mistakes. Smaller puzzles also suffer as they can become simple exercises in trial and error.Yet that flaw is a minor complaint. Anyone who enjoys logic-based puzzles should give this one a go. After finishing it, check out Hexcells Plus for an even greater challenge or Hexcells Infinite for an endless amount of content.

Posted: November 15, 2014
												Some compare Hexcells to Minesweeper, but it is not quite the same.  With Minesweeper, winning fells like the luck of the draw rather than a logic exercise.  Luck adds a certain flair to other types of games, but with puzzle games like this, it does not do the game any favors.  Fortunately, Hexcells does not make the player rely on luck to complete puzzles.Hexcells forces you to use reason and logic to solve a puzzle.  The goal of each puzzle is to clear the orange hexagons to reveal a certain pattern.  The numbers in each cell indicate how many surrounding cells are part of the pattern (this is where the similarity to Minesweeper comes in).  As you progress, new elements are added.  These elements are reminsicent of Picross.  There is a number above the column that indicates how many cells in that column are part of the ultimate pattern.  There are also numbers in brackets that tell you how many cells are connected.  The puzzles also get larger.This is a relaxing puzzle game that is definitely worth the time if you enjoy logic puzzles.  It took me about 4.5 hours to complete 30 puzzles.

												I got Hexcells Plus as part of a bundle, and after playing the first few levels I immediately purchased Hexcells so that I could play them in order. I didn't expect to enjoy these games as much as I did. The games are a mix of Minesweeper and Sodoku, plus a few extra twists.This game ran very well on my netbook at 1024x600 resolution (CPU: 1GHz dual-core AMD C-50), so I think that virtually any computer will be able to hande this game. If you are contemplating buying this game then you might as well get the Hexcells Bundle with both games (especially if you are proficient at logic puzzles). The difficulty curve in the second game starts exactly where the first game ended.All the levels can be completed without having to resort to guessing, although sometimes you wont believe this. But even when you are unable to determine (for example) which two cells contain the mine, knowing that it is either one or the other may give you enough of a clue to clear a third cell. It is very satisfying when you eventually figure out the puzzle.The only real con that I found to this game was that despite the harder levels taking some time to complete, there is a great sense of wanting to play just one more level when you do manage to finish it. This can be lead to some very late nights!Finally, a tip. If you are used to playing Minesweeper, you might like to swap the left & right mouse button actions in the configuration screen so that the right mouse button flags a cell as a blue cell (or a mine in Minesweeper parlance). I kept making mistakes all the time until I did this.

Posted: February 27, 2015
												I bought this short but sweet game when it was on sale for 50 cents. I didn't expect much, so it was a pleasant surprise to find a true logic game.Though Hexcells borrows elements from several different puzzle games, I was most reminded of nonograms, also known as Picross or Hanjie, which I've solved hundreds of by hand and in video games. As with nonograms, the game's beauty lies in the fact that the rules are are simple and it is purely logic-based (instead of relying on gimmicks or time-limits). That means that even in the later puzzles, which can be a bit challenging, you never have to resort to guess-work and anyone can solve them easily with enough focus and time.It's true the game was far too short (you can get 100% completion in a few hours), but now that I've tried it I would recommend it even at full price, though of course preferably wait for a sale. Apparently, the third installment has a random puzzle generator, which soundss like exactly the kind of thing this kind of game needs, but I will have to try it to see. Regardless, this game has proven the concept amazingly well and given my brains a few solid hours of work to do for the price of a cup of coffee.

What is Hexcells?Hexcells is a puzzle game that looks rather like Minesweeper. Players are presented with an orange grid comprised to hexagons and it is up to them to determine whether these cells belong to the blue pattern or not (black cells). The black cells not part of the pattern have a number in them to indicate how many blue cells are adjacent to them, thus providing a clue as to how to proceed.After completing a puzzle the player is awarded blue hexcells based on the amount of mistakes made; these in time accumulate to unlock one of five new areas - allowing you to complete more difficult puzzles. Some areas also introduce new clues and rules to help you, making the puzzles more complex over time. Although similar to Minesweeper as mentioned, there is a key difference: there is always a logical next step. You never have to take a gamble so if you feel stuck, take a step back and focus on another area.Why I recommend the gameHexcells is a very simple puzzle game in its visual design. The menu is simple and provides the players with the option of turning the ambient music on or off and selecting one of three save slots. The same can be said for the puzzles themselves; a grid of hexagons on a white backdrop. To me this is good design, as I'm here for the puzzles and that's where the focus clearly lies.The 30 puzzles themselves are interesting and there are enough additions in terms of new rules/clues during the course of a playthrough to keep them fresh and interesting. I just wish there were more.However, this does not mean that the game is without flaws. For instance, it is not possible to erase a save slot so starting completely from scratch is not an option if all three slots are in use. Furthermore, the puzzles tend to be on the easy side, for me anyways.My biggest problem with the game is that there is no option to save mid-puzzle forcing you to either finish it or redo the part you already completed next time.All that being said, I've had a lot of fun playing this game and would recommend it as the pros outweigh the cons for me. I would encourage those interested in puzzle games to give this one a try.

			Kick back for a relaxing puzzle game called Hexcells today. Well relaxing in the Sudoku sense. Hexcells puts you in charge of what hexagons need to be changed, or not.		

Yesterday I had a headache, and was searching for a game that I could play to get my mind off of it. I wanted something without action, and I wanted to listen to some of my own relaxing music. I knew a puzzle game would be a perfect fit, and that's how I came across Hexcells. So I put on my music, and got right to the relaxing world of math.Hexcells is a game where a bunch of hexagons come together, and you must figure out if the orange hexagons are blue, or a number. Sound simple sure, but how does one figure out this crazy math! Each puzzle starts off showing some numbered hexagons. This number is equal to the amount of blue hexagons that are touching it. So if it says four that means four blue hexagons are touching, and if it says zero then that means no blue ones are touching.Let's stay with the zero example for a little bit. So if it says zero then you'll want to right click all the hexagons that are touching it. This gives you more options to play around with as it opens up more of the playing field. For another example lets move on to if the hexagon says one. Since this one already is touching a blue hexagon then you can right click on all the other hexagons touching this hexagon with the number one.Hexcells was a great way to just kick back, and play a mindless game that actually requires some brainpower. Think of it like a Sudoku, or word search puzzle. You're using your brain, but it's not something you have to concentrate too hard on.As Hexcells carried on it added more rules to it. One for example was having numbers at the top, or sides of the puzzle. When you see this number that's telling you how many blue hexagons are in that row. There's more to the world of Hexcells, but that's for you to find out about.It took me a little over two hours to beat Hexcells, and I was kind of sad it was over so soon. I want more puzzles! I really enjoyed my time figuring out these puzzles, and think if you're a fan of Sudoku puzzles, or puzzles in general you'll enjoy Hexcells. Worth the price of $2.99, and worth your time.

												The best way I can think of to describe Hexcells is not as a puzzle game, but as a "meditation game" and a sort of mental massage.The gameplay follows on from Minesweeper, you start with the same rules, identifying blue hexes by the non-blue hexes telling you the number of adjacent blues. Quick Breakdown: A fun puzzle game with similarities to Minesweeper, where you must determine which cells are filled with blue hexes, and which are vacant.Length: 2-3 hoursScore: 6/10Full Review: Hexcells a simple puzzle game, its closest companion would be Minesweeper, except it’s a bit more involved than that (also a lot better, and you’re not timed). The way the game works is you have a… let’s call it a board, filled with hexagons, which we’ll call cells. You need to determine which cells are occupied with a blue hexagon, and which ones are vacant (which will be grey). The vacant cells will also have a number inside them, indicating how many adjacent cells are occupied. You simply left click a cell to mark it as occupied, and right click a cell to mark it as vacant. If you’re correct, the cell will change accordingly. If you’re wrong, it’ll shake and mark you as getting making a mistake (more on this in a moment).As you progress through the game, the puzzles will get more complicated, and additional ways to indicate whether or not a cell is occupied are introduced.  Sometimes numbers will be encased in curly brackets, indicating that all the occupied cells adjacent to the vacant cell are touching each other.  Where-as a number that has a hyphen on each side means that at least one of the adjacent occupied cells is not touching the other adjacent occupied cells. (Note for clarity: When I say the cells are touching each other, I don’t mean ALL the cells are touching ALL the other cells, but that they are connected like a line curved around the vacant cell. For the hyphenated numbers, some of the cells may be touching each other, but there is at least one break in the group. There may be two groups of two touching cells for example).Numbers will also appear at the top of columns, or even at a diagonal, indicating how many occupied cells are in that row or column (reminding me ever so slightly of Picross). This numbers also will use the same additional mechanics as the vacant cells, with the curly braces and hyphens indicating if the cells are all connected, or have a break in them. The later stages will require you to use these different numbers in tandem to solve the puzzle.Now, even in the later stages of the game, Hexcells never gets too difficult. It’s a fairly easy game, and you’ll be able to complete it in 2-3 hours without much trouble. After that, you’re done, there’s not much replay value (unless you try to perfect every level, which you might do just playing through it anyway).The levels in Hexcells are divided up into 6 worlds. Each world consists of a couple of stages (4-6 stages, with a total of 26 stages). When you complete a level you are awarded blue hexes towards a total score of them. By earning enough of these blue hexes you unlock the next world. The number of blue hexes awarded for completing a stage varies depending on its difficulty, and you will be awarded less blue hexes the more mistakes you make in a level. (Don’t worry, you can redo levels do earn the blue hexes you missed).The music in the game is fairly calm and simple, it’s not anything particularly note-worthy, but it fits with the relaxed feel of the game. (Both the game and the music are overall rather relaxing).As for criticisms, they’re two main things I feel this game lacks. 1). There’s no option to save a level mid-way through, so that you can leave the game and return to it later. My work around for this was to take a screen cap if I had to stop playing for some reason, and then just redo my stage progress from there. 2). It’d be nice if there was a way to map out a potential solution (similar to Picross’ overlay feature), so that you can indicate which cells you think may contain blue hexes, and which you think may be vacant without selecting them. Though, this is less needed in this Hexcells game than it is in later ones where you must figure out how large swathes of a level work together to determine if a cell has a blue hex or not.So if you’re into puzzle games, then consider picking up the Hexcells pack when it goes on sale (often you can get all 3 games for less than $3). If you already have the first Hexcells game and want more, Hexcells Plus is basically the hard mode for this game, and Hexcells infinite will also provide you with more puzzles to play. If you only want one Hexcells game, go for Infinite, it has some improvements over the other two, and a random level generator, so it’ll offer more play time, (see my review for Hexcells Infinite for more details on that). Whichever route you opt for, it’s a fun puzzle game.

Posted: January 3, 2016
												80 minutes to get 98%. Recommended for fans of Minesweeper/Picross, at the price that you feel is appropriate for about 1.5 hours of play.I have a fair amount of experience with Minesweeper and Picross-style puzzles, so this felt straightforward and fun. Hexcells ends up using the same logic you'd use for those games. All puzzles are 100% prove-able; there's no forced guessing between multiple spaces. I didn't notice anywhere that I had to string together much "if this, then this, then this, no that won't work"...no giant cascading logic messes. Comfortable and casual all the way through.Some cautions: -- Unlike some similar games, you aren't marking tiles in a toggle-able way. That is, once you left- or right-click on a tile, it will immediately be shown to be correct or incorrect (which costs you a mistake). -- To me, the default left and right click felt backwards. I restarted the game and swapped them in the pre-game settings window with no problem. -- I played through almost the entire game in a windowed smaller resolution. Puzzle 29 did not fit entirely in the window, and I couldn't find any way to scroll or scale so I could see the whole puzzle. I had to exit back out and start again with non-windowed 1080p, since I figured that would be safe for all puzzles. -- The level select screen does not seem to indicate which puzzles you used a "mistake" on, so it looks like it would be annoying to go back and figure that out after the fact. I'd recommend that you immediately retry puzzles if you're aiming for the (very obtainable) perfect achievement, or at least write down which puzzles you'd need to retry later.Don't get me wrong, these cautions are all very minor. I enjoyed this quick game.

Posted: September 14, 2014
Hexcells has been aptly described as a modern version of Minesweeper. There are several key differences, however: Minesweeper randomly generates its levels, while each level in Hexcells was created by hand. This gives it the advantage that every level is solvable using pure logic, no need for guessing. Hexcells is also more lenient when it comes to making mistakes: it counts how many mistakes you make, but they do not result in a game over. Instead, you must solve each level with a minimum of mistakes in order to earn a perfect score.Creating each level by hand also has the disadvantage of limiting the game to a finite number of levels. There are so few in fact that it only took me two hours to complete every level with no mistakes. Because of this I would not recommend spending more than $2 on it.

												I think this is, quite literally, the perfect puzzle game. It has a learning curve smoother than any other and just the right amount of difficulty to keep you thinking the entire time, but not roadblocking you. While it can look too simple with a very limited ruleset, it pushes the mechanics to their limit. If you're familiar with logic puzzles, it MIGHT be too easy for you, but I found it to be so much more satisfying than any other puzzle game I've played. Minesweeper is similar, but it's lucked based, and this game can be completed doing zero guesses, since it's all pure logic. Games like kami on steam can be fun, but it's too easy to guess the solution than to really think and problem solve using logic, and often similar games will just pile on more rules and gimmicks, but not Hexcells. 												Short but a nice bit of puzzle fun. Simple Minesweeper meets Pattern kind of logical puzzle. Later levels are very enjoyable.The game is very short. No replayability. Clicking cells emits a sound fitting the harmony of the ambient background track. Everything feels like music and that's beautiful.Graphics are decent for a puzzle game with simple design. Unfortunately, poor framerate and cursor flickering. Seriously, this needs optimizing as it gnaws on the game experience.Recommended if you're looking for a round of chill puzzles and don't mind the stuttering. Posted: May 16, 2016
												Hexcells is an excellent puzzle game with mechanics very similar to Minesweeper. Your goal is to discover fields where the 'bombs' are and correctly mark them by eliminating empty ones. They are represented by numbers which show how many bombs there are in adjacent cells. Additional rules are introduced in later levels such as number of bombs in whole column and that they must be either adjacent to one another or separate from each other.Game has 30 levels which will take you between 1 and 1.5 hours to complete. Warm recommendation for purchasing Hexcells Complete Pack which contains all 3 games from this series.

Posted: June 28, 2015
												Hexcells is one of the best puzzle game experiences I've had.It starts off with a simple Minesweeper-like premise. After a few levels, the game begins its brilliance by adding new types of clues beyond "three of the surrounding hexes are empty," turning the game into something resembling a nonogram-like puzzle (the kind of puzzle featured in Nintendo's Picross games). These mechanics are backed up by excellent puzzle design and an ambient soundtrack that keeps players relaxed and focused as they work their way through the puzzles.The only serious flaw in the game is that there isn't any replay value. There is still quite a bit of skill in repeating the large puzzles without making a mistake, but gradually players will remember the patterns and can cheat by learning from previous mistakes. Smaller puzzles also suffer as they can become simple exercises in trial and error.Yet that flaw is a minor complaint. Anyone who enjoys logic-based puzzles should give this one a go. After finishing it, check out Hexcells Plus for an even greater challenge or Hexcells Infinite for an endless amount of content.

												Nothing prepared me for what this game has done to me. I was looking for a puzzle game and came across Hexcell as one of Steam’s recommendations. “For two bucks and some change, I’ll give it a shot,” I thought. The game lulled me into relaxation by introducing concepts in easy to understand tutorials and basic puzzles. Then it added another layer of complexity, then another, and another. After finally completing one of the later puzzles without making any errors, I realized that I was not just playing a game. I was being trained on how to thing rationally and methodically using geometric and mathematical principles in ways that were light years beyond anything I had ever encountered before. At times, the game has taunted me, frustrated me, and even seemed to take a delight in watching me click on the wrong hex after getting three quarters through a map. Yet, I always go back for more. 												Hexcells and its sequels are absolutely essential to anyone that loves logic puzzle games like Picross and Sudoku. Contrary to the belief of the occasional negative (bad) reviewer, there is ALWAYS a logical way to proceed, without any guesswork. It often requires that you change the way you think about solving the puzzles, as following the same rules will only take you so far. Particularly, when it gets to the point that you have to start systematically eliminating cells as possible answers one at a time, or weighing your options based on the number of blue cells remaining, I can see why certain players would simply give up and call it impossible. It's not; I promise. Keep at it, or try to find a spoiler free hint to give you an idea of how to think through it rather than just giving you the answers.

Posted: January 3, 2016
												80 minutes to get 98%. Recommended for fans of Minesweeper/Picross, at the price that you feel is appropriate for about 1.5 hours of play.I have a fair amount of experience with Minesweeper and Picross-style puzzles, so this felt straightforward and fun. Hexcells ends up using the same logic you'd use for those games. All puzzles are 100% prove-able; there's no forced guessing between multiple spaces. I didn't notice anywhere that I had to string together much "if this, then this, then this, no that won't work"...no giant cascading logic messes. Comfortable and casual all the way through.Some cautions: -- Unlike some similar games, you aren't marking tiles in a toggle-able way. That is, once you left- or right-click on a tile, it will immediately be shown to be correct or incorrect (which costs you a mistake). -- To me, the default left and right click felt backwards. I restarted the game and swapped them in the pre-game settings window with no problem. -- I played through almost the entire game in a windowed smaller resolution. Puzzle 29 did not fit entirely in the window, and I couldn't find any way to scroll or scale so I could see the whole puzzle. I had to exit back out and start again with non-windowed 1080p, since I figured that would be safe for all puzzles. -- The level select screen does not seem to indicate which puzzles you used a "mistake" on, so it looks like it would be annoying to go back and figure that out after the fact. I'd recommend that you immediately retry puzzles if you're aiming for the (very obtainable) perfect achievement, or at least write down which puzzles you'd need to retry later.Don't get me wrong, these cautions are all very minor. I enjoyed this quick game.

												Note: This review is for both Hexcells, Hexcells Plus and Hexcells Infinite, because they're basically a single game divided in three parts.The Hexcell games are a series of brilliant crafted puzzles that at first glance may seem like a six-sided minesweeper, but the logic used to solve them is closer to sudoku. As you progress through the levels, you are also introduced to some new mechanics accompained by a tutorial level to make sure that you understand them. Because the puzzles are carefully and wonderfully designed, you never have to guess your next move, but finding it gets hard in the later puzzles. The interface is clean and the sound effects are cool. Hexcells is easy, Hexcells Plus gets harder in the second half and Hexcells Infinite steps back a little at the beginning, but in the end offers the most challenging puzzles. It also comes with a seed-based puzzle generator, adding 999,999,999 additional puzzles (even if they aren't hand crafted, they're still good). My recommendation is that you get and play all three games in order, but if you can only pick one, pick Hexcells Infinite, it's main levels difficulty is nicely spread not to mention the puzzle generator.

Posted: February 15, 2016
												HexcellsA nice, relaxing puzzle game, set to a calm set of background noises and music that tickles the brain just enough to see it to the end. A super short game that doesn't take long to finish the game or even the achievements. It has a few flaws, but then again, what game isn't?Abstract - Hexcells is a short puzzle game involving numbers, hexagons, and a bit of thinking. It's short, sweet, not all that problematic, and fun for anyone looking for a little puzzle fix.What it is -  Its a puzzle game, pretty straight forward. No huge plot or anything.Who you are - The puzzle solver!What you do in game - Solve the puzzles using the context clues and hints provided by clicking the different cells. Two counters appear at the top, the remaining blue cells that need to be revealed, and the mistake counter, which affects how many "reward cells" you get upon finishing a level. The higher your mistake count, the less you earn. Gameplay - The aim of the game is to find all the blue cells while making few to no mistakes as possible. Finding all the blue cells and revealing the hint cells will finish the level. You need a set amount of "reward cells" in order to open up the newer levels, increasing in amount the further you go along. The game itself is an enjoyable experience, and, for the most part, not all that difficult. It becomes a little painful at the end, but the biggest complaint is how often "guesstimating" is your only option. You can easily narrow down where the blue cells will be, but more often than not you'll end up guessing about where the blue cells could be. Some are smart guesses, others are just "welp, I'm stumped!" guesses. It kinda detracted from the idea of solving the puzzle using smarts.Messing up isn't the end of the world. You can simply come back to the level later to try for fewer mistakes. That said, one can simply get the solution by purposefully using the screenshot function, but that's more of a "last resort", so don't abuse it!Envionment - White background, orange hexagons. Kinda strains the eye after a while, so take breaks!Conclusion - Really, especially for the price, its a pretty smooth game. Guesstimations aside, its a game that keeps you thinking, doesn't punish you too hard for playing the game and making mistakes as you can always come back to play at your own pace. The game also has several parts so you can easily extend your play sessions with different puzzles. If you're a hardcore puzzle lover, give this a pass. Too easy, exploitable, relies too much on guessing. If you just enjoy a good puzzle to pass the time, pick it right up!

Posted: May 24, 2016
												Hexcells is a relatively simple puzzle game similar in some ways to mineweeper.   An array of hexes is presented and  you need to left click (reveal  a filled cell) or right click to reveal a non-filled cell.   However, it is vastly different from minesweeper in that each puzzle can be solved logicially wihout guesswork.   Each revealed cell shows the number of adjacent filled cells, but there can be other clues as well, for example, the number of filled cells in a column, row, or diagonal.  In this way it also reminds me a of sudoko puzzles.   There is no timer, and if you make a mistake you can either continue on or restart to try for a "pefect" solution, so one can procede at whatever pace you like.Very enjoyable if you like this sort of logic puzzle.

Posted: May 29, 2016
												A nice relaxing puzzle. Very reminiscent of minesweeper, and additional elements added later on also reminded me of Picross. I completed the game on a lazy Saturday and it gave me enough challenge that it didn't feel like a breeze. Additionally, it never vexed me by being too difficult or requiring me to know the intricacies of how everything worked (those hidden rules you find after doing a puzzle for a long time). If there's one thing to note, it's that the "Perfectionist" achievement does NOT require you to get 0 mistakes on all levels, just to get all of those hexagonal "points". This is good, because there's several levels where I got 1 honest mistake and it didn't deduct anything.The game also punishes random "spam n' solve" play by making it impossible to unlock later levels without X number of aforementioned hexagonal points. Why you would do that anyway is beyond me.My only critique of the game is a lack of puzzles with all the elements added. Initially, the game starts off by showing you the base points, then shows you that lines and columns can have numbers too, and then shows you how to toggle everything; and suddenly, you're two-thirds of the way through the puzzles. Just a minor gripe, but getting Hexcells Plus & Infinite solves that problem nicely.

												Hexcells is a logic puzzle that's similar to other number games like Minesweeper and Picross, as you use processes of elimination and deduction to fill in patterns of tiles. The distinction here is that since the tiles are hexagons, they're not restricted by square grids, and most puzzles look like abstract shapes or very loosely defined objects.  hexes have numbers on them from 0 to 6 indicating how many of the gold tiles around them can be clicked to turn blue, which counts toward stage completion.-This game made my brain explode  LOL -Not relax game xD-Have fun.

Posted: January 19
Reasons why I'm recommending this game:1. Enjoyable puzzling - even though the core concept is very simple, enough mechanics are introduced to vary things up. 2. Pure logic puzzles - you can guess, but you never have to. There is always a way to figure out the puzzle 100% without mistakes. This is also true of the following games (Hexcells Plus and Hexcells Infinity, though they increase the difficulty significantly). 3. Very clean, functional and nice interface.Overall I had a lot of fun with this game and its two sequels. While the core concept is similar to minesweeper, the added mechanics and the fact that you never have to guess to solve the puzzles makes it a far superior game to its inspiration. Recommended for anyone who likes pure logic games.
